articles.headline: How to Pay for College With Less Stress
articles.snippet: An adviser has a four-step plan to prepare for the financial gantlet that is your child’s college education.
articles.abstract: An adviser has a four-step plan to prepare for the financial gantlet that is your child’s college education.
articles.lead_paragraph: In this our quadrennial season of financial hope, we might wish that the major presidential candidates would reckon with one of the large and looming numbers in our lives.

articles.headline: ‘Doomsday Today in Aleppo’: Assad and Russian Forces Bombard City
articles.snippet: Repeated airstrikes that destroyed buildings and killed about 100 people came with the threat of a ground invasion, as efforts at the United Nations to revive a truce appeared to collapse.
articles.abstract: Repeated airstrikes that destroyed buildings and killed about 100 people came with the threat of a ground invasion, as efforts at the United Nations to revive a truce appeared to collapse.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — Syria’s war escalated abruptly on Friday as government forces and their Russian allies launched ferocious aerial assaults on opposition-held areas of Aleppo amid threats of a big ground offensive, while efforts at the United Nations to revive a cease-fire appeared to collapse.

articles.headline: Your Mutual Fund Has Your Proxy, Like It or Not
articles.snippet: If you invest with a large fund manager, chances are good that your objections to common corporate practices are not getting through.
articles.abstract: If you invest with a large fund manager, chances are good that your objections to common corporate practices are not getting through.
articles.lead_paragraph: Do you think executive compensation is out of control or that a company should have to disclose its political contributions?

articles.headline: Video by Wife of Keith Scott Shows Her Pleas to Police
articles.snippet: The video does not include a view of the shooting itself. Nor does it answer the crucial question of whether Mr. Scott was brandishing a gun, as police have maintained.
articles.abstract: The video does not include a view of the shooting itself. Nor does it answer the crucial question of whether Mr. Scott was brandishing a gun, as police have maintained.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — A cellphone video made by the wife of Keith Lamont Scott as he was fatally shot by the police here shows the moments before and after the episode, including the wife’s pleas to her husband to get out of his truck, and her pleas to the officers not to shoot him.
articles.byline: By Richard Fausset and Yamiche Alcindor

articles.headline: Facebook Apologizes for Overstating Video Metrics
articles.snippet: The social media network was leaving out videos viewed for less than three seconds, which greatly inflated the figures presented to advertisers and publishers.
articles.abstract: The social media network was leaving out videos viewed for less than three seconds, which greatly inflated the figures presented to advertisers and publishers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Facebook apologized on Friday for an error in the way it measured video viewership, a miscalculation that greatly overstated how much time, on average, its users were spending watching videos.
articles.byline: By John Herrman and Sapna Maheshwari

articles.headline: Twitter Is Said to Be Discussing a Possible Takeover
articles.snippet: The social network site has been considering a possible restructuring as it wrestles with a slowdown in its growth.
articles.abstract: The social network site has been considering a possible restructuring as it wrestles with a slowdown in its growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: Twitter has long positioned itself as a global town square where anyone — celebrities, politicians, athletes, and you and me — can chat in 140-character messages and find out about whatever is happening in the moment.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac, Katie Benner and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: What the Hacking at Yahoo Means for Verizon
articles.snippet: Questions swirl about whether Verizon’s $4.8 billion deal for Yahoo’s core business will be renegotiated, or happen at all.
articles.abstract: Questions swirl about whether Verizon’s $4.8 billion deal for Yahoo’s core business will be renegotiated, or happen at all.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was the kind of phone call no chief executive wants to make — or receive — in the middle of a multibillion-dollar deal.

articles.headline: Haitians, After Perilous Journey, Find Door to U.S. Abruptly Shut
articles.snippet: After a trek through Latin America many migrants thought they were just days from entering the United States, but a shift in American policy has left them stranded.
articles.abstract: After a trek through Latin America many migrants thought they were just days from entering the United States, but a shift in American policy has left them stranded.
articles.lead_paragraph: TIJUANA, Mexico — They passed the corpses of other migrants who had tried to cross the Americas. They were cheated by smugglers and fleeced by armed bandits, and they suffered long stretches of hunger.

articles.headline: Hackers Trawl User Data in Hopes a Small Target Will Lead to a Big One
articles.snippet: By perusing personal accounts of people with even the thinnest thread of a connection to power, hackers can find their way to high-level government officials.
articles.abstract: By perusing personal accounts of people with even the thinnest thread of a connection to power, hackers can find their way to high-level government officials.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In disclosing that at least 500 million of its user accounts had been hacked, Yahoo blamed an unnamed “state-sponsored actor” for the intrusion. While Yahoo customers were caught by surprise, officials in Washington were not.

articles.headline: Tulsa’s Prayers, and Past Scars, Softened Reaction to Police Shooting
articles.snippet: Some residents attribute Tulsa’s calm after a police shooting to religious restraint and the memories of a 1921 riot that left as many as 300 dead.
articles.abstract: Some residents attribute Tulsa’s calm after a police shooting to religious restraint and the memories of a 1921 riot that left as many as 300 dead.
articles.lead_paragraph: TULSA, Okla. — White rioters poured into the streets, burning and looting homes, businesses and churches in a black neighborhood and leaving this city deeply traumatized. That was 1921.
articles.byline: By Manny Fernandez and Michael Wines

articles.headline: In an Era of Hyperbole, Paul Bunyan Is as Tall as Ever
articles.snippet: Many Minnesotans still hold a gargantuan lumberjack in reverence, but anything seems possible in this era, and election, of hyperbole.
articles.abstract: Many Minnesotans still hold a gargantuan lumberjack in reverence, but anything seems possible in this era, and election, of hyperbole.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEMIDJI, Minn. — He’s huge in Minnesota. Huge.

articles.headline: In Australia, China’s Appetite Shifts From Rocks to Real Estate
articles.snippet: China’s breakneck growth fueled an iron ore boom in Western Australia. Now, Chinese investors are fleeing a cooling economy by investing in Australian homes.
articles.abstract: China’s breakneck growth fueled an iron ore boom in Western Australia. Now, Chinese investors are fleeing a cooling economy by investing in Australian homes.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORT HEDLAND, Australia — A lanky, dark-haired surfer, Lee Meadowcroft modeled on the runways of London, Milan and Singapore, then followed his dream of going home to Australia to sell herbal medicines. His store failed — he had chosen the wrong street, he says — and he lost almost all his savings. By then, the fashion world had found fresher faces.

articles.headline: Phone Makers Could Cut Off Drivers. So Why Don’t They?
articles.snippet: Apple and digital giants have developed potentially lifesaving technology to block texting while driving, but it’s still not being deployed.
articles.abstract: Apple and digital giants have developed potentially lifesaving technology to block texting while driving, but it’s still not being deployed.
articles.lead_paragraph: The court filings paint a grisly picture: As Ashley Kubiak sped down a Texas highway in her Dodge Ram truck, she checked her iPhone for messages. Distracted, she crashed into a sport utility vehicle, killing its driver and a passenger and leaving a child paralyzed.

articles.headline: Clinton-Trump Debate Expected to Be Rare Draw in a Polarized Age
articles.snippet: The total audience, network executives and political strategists say, could be as high as 100 million viewers — Super Bowl territory.
articles.abstract: The total audience, network executives and political strategists say, could be as high as 100 million viewers — Super Bowl territory.
articles.lead_paragraph: The uniquely uncivil presidential campaign is about to produce one of the biggest civic gatherings in decades: For 90 minutes on Monday night, a polarized nation will pause to watch the first head-to-head encounter between Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump.

articles.headline: Young Rural Women in India Chase Big-City Dreams
articles.snippet: Experiments like one in Bangalore, luring migrants to fill factory jobs, collide with an old way of life that keeps women and girls in seclusion until an arranged marriage.
articles.abstract: Experiments like one in Bangalore, luring migrants to fill factory jobs, collide with an old way of life that keeps women and girls in seclusion until an arranged marriage.
articles.lead_paragraph: BANGALORE, India — The factory floor is going full throttle when the new girls walk in. Everywhere is the thrumming of sewing machines, the hum of fans, the faint burning smell of steam irons. On narrow tables that run between the machines, half-assembled Marks & Spencer miniskirts are thrust forward by fistfuls. The tailors, absorbed in the task of finishing 100 pieces per hour, for once turn their heads to look.

articles.headline: 2008 Crisis Deepened the Ties Between Clintons and Goldman Sachs
articles.snippet: One of the country’s most powerful financial firms and one of its most famous political families have a long-running and mutually beneficial relationship.
articles.abstract: One of the country’s most powerful financial firms and one of its most famous political families have a long-running and mutually beneficial relationship.
articles.lead_paragraph: A blue-ribbon commission had just excoriated Goldman Sachs and other Wall Street banks for fueling the financial crisis. Prosecutors were investigating whether Goldman had misled investors. The company was a whipping boy for politicians looking to lay blame for the crash.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Confessore and Susanne Craig

articles.headline: Yielding to Pressure, Charlotte Releases Videos of Keith Scott Shooting
articles.snippet: City officials released dashboard and body camera recordings in the fatal police shooting after they were pressed by politicians, community leaders and protesters.
articles.abstract: City officials released dashboard and body camera recordings in the fatal police shooting after they were pressed by politicians, community leaders and protesters.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Under mounting pressure from politicians, community leaders and boisterous protesters who have brought this city’s main business district to a near standstill, the Charlotte police chief on Saturday released body and dashboard camera videos of the fatal police shooting of Keith Lamont Scott, a black resident here.
articles.byline: By Richard Fausset, Alan Blinder and Yamiche Alcindor

articles.headline: Syria and Russia Appear Ready to Scorch Aleppo
articles.snippet: The Syrians and Russians appear to be mobilizing to apply a kill-all-who-resist strategy to their most ambitious target yet.
articles.abstract: The Syrians and Russians appear to be mobilizing to apply a kill-all-who-resist strategy to their most ambitious target yet.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Make life intolerable and death likely. Open an escape route, or offer a deal to those who leave or surrender. Let people trickle out. Kill whoever stays. Repeat until a deserted cityscape is yours.
articles.byline: By Anne Barnard and Somini Sengupta

articles.headline: A Moment of Truth for Presidential Debate Moderators
articles.snippet: News outlets and fact-checking sites can separate truth from fable after a debate, but it falls to the moderator to interject in the moment when a candidate lies.
articles.abstract: News outlets and fact-checking sites can separate truth from fable after a debate, but it falls to the moderator to interject in the moment when a candidate lies.
articles.lead_paragraph: If this hasn’t been the worst year ever for truth in politics, I can’t think of what was. Nor can anyone tell me.

articles.headline: What if ‘One Click’ Buying Were Internetwide?
articles.snippet: Top internet companies — but not Amazon or PayPal — are cooperating to solve a persistent problem: How to provide one-click shopping across all kinds of sites.
articles.abstract: Top internet companies — but not Amazon or PayPal — are cooperating to solve a persistent problem: How to provide one-click shopping across all kinds of sites.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Paying for things online can be cumbersome. Even the man who invented the web, Tim Berners-Lee, says he frequently throws up his hands.

articles.headline: A Choice Beyond Cable Box Rentals? It May Hinge on a Swing Voter
articles.snippet: An F.C.C. commissioner may not side with her fellow Democrats on a plan that would make it easier to combine streaming services and cable channels on one device.
articles.abstract: An F.C.C. commissioner may not side with her fellow Democrats on a plan that would make it easier to combine streaming services and cable channels on one device.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the Federal Communications Commission announced a plan this year that would free people from having to rent cable set-top boxes, the cable and television industries balked and lobbied hard to forestall the proposal.

articles.headline: Making Video Ads That Work on Facebook’s Silent Screen
articles.snippet: Marketers trying to reach an increasingly fractured and fickle social media audience are struggling to make ads when one version may not work everywhere.
articles.abstract: Marketers trying to reach an increasingly fractured and fickle social media audience are struggling to make ads when one version may not work everywhere.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE GEICO commercial that made its premiere this summer seemed like a standard 30-second television ad. It features two men building sand castles on a pristine beach with their children. “Guess what I just did?” one of the men asks. “Built a sand castle?” the other responds. “Ha — no. I switched to Geico and got more,” the first man says.
articles.byline: By Sapna Maheshwari and Katie Benner

articles.headline: Court Leader or Leading Dissenter? Chief Justice’s Fate Tied to Election
articles.snippet: A pick by President Obama or Hillary Clinton would put Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. in the minority in many close cases, or even nudge him to the left.
articles.abstract: A pick by President Obama or Hillary Clinton would put Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. in the minority in many close cases, or even nudge him to the left.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr.’s 11 years on the Supreme Court, his unfolding legacy has been marked by a debate over whether his very occasional liberal votes in major cases were the acts of a statesman devoted to his institution, a traitor to his principles or the legal umpire he said he aspired to be at his confirmation hearings.

articles.headline: Grit vs. Goliath: A Reporter’s Dogged Pursuit of Roger Ailes
articles.snippet: The reporter Gabriel Sherman has been spied on, insulted and threatened as he has taken on the powerful and volatile former Fox chairman Roger Ailes.
articles.abstract: The reporter Gabriel Sherman has been spied on, insulted and threatened as he has taken on the powerful and volatile former Fox chairman Roger Ailes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Anyone visiting the Rockefeller Center studios of MSNBC on Sept. 2 would have witnessed a peculiar spectacle: the reporter Gabriel Sherman arriving for an on-air interview accompanied by a bodyguard.

articles.headline: Millions in U.S. Climb Out of Poverty, at Long Last
articles.snippet: In 2015, 3.5 million Americans were able to breach the poverty line as an economic recovery hit a tipping point.
articles.abstract: In 2015, 3.5 million Americans were able to breach the poverty line as an economic recovery hit a tipping point.
articles.lead_paragraph: Not that long ago, Alex Caicedo was stuck working a series of odd jobs and watching his 1984 Chevy Nova cough its last breaths. He could make $21 an hour at the Johnny Rockets food stand at FedEx Field when the Washington Redskins were playing, but the work was spotty.

articles.headline: First Clinton-Trump Debate Is Framed by Rifts Over Race and Gender
articles.snippet: In a campaign that is now a battle over national identity and values, the candidates are more opposed over race and gender than any in decades.
articles.abstract: In a campaign that is now a battle over national identity and values, the candidates are more opposed over race and gender than any in decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump are spoiling for an extraordinary clash over race and gender that could come as early as Monday’s debate, with both presidential candidates increasingly staking their fortunes on the cultural issues that are convulsing the nation.
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: Inside France’s ‘Jungle’: Desperate Migrants Keep Coming to Calais
articles.snippet: The camp perched at the edge of the English Channel has doubled in size, a highly visible symbol of Europe’s inability to cope with the migrant influx.
articles.abstract: The camp perched at the edge of the English Channel has doubled in size, a highly visible symbol of Europe’s inability to cope with the migrant influx.
articles.lead_paragraph: CALAIS, France — The migrants from Afghanistan, Sudan, Eritrea and elsewhere keep coming. Almost 100 a day arrive at this dusty, ramshackle camp perched at the edge of the English Channel, just 31 miles from Britain, their ultimate goal.
articles.byline: By Adam Nossiter and Tyler Hicks

articles.headline: A New Debate Over Pricing the Risks of Climate Change
articles.snippet: Exxon Mobil says it’s not possible to predict how climate change will affect its business. A bill in Congress says it shouldn’t be asked to.
articles.abstract: Exxon Mobil says it’s not possible to predict how climate change will affect its business. A bill in Congress says it shouldn’t be asked to.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some companies, including Exxon Mobil, say the economics of climate change are too hard to predict for them to give investors hard numbers about the business impact of global warming.
articles.byline: By Hiroko Tabuchi and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: U.S. Murders Surged in 2015, F.B.I. Finds
articles.snippet: The 10.8 percent increase in the rate of murders from 2014 to 2015 was the largest year-to-year increase in at least 20 years, a report from the bureau said.
articles.abstract: The 10.8 percent increase in the rate of murders from 2014 to 2015 was the largest year-to-year increase in at least 20 years, a report from the bureau said.
articles.lead_paragraph: The country’s murder rate jumped more last year than it had in nearly half a century, newly released federal crime data showed, although the number of homicides remained far below the levels of the 1980s and ’90s.
articles.byline: By Timothy Williams and Monica Davey
